lcInstruction.p: Instead of using the DITA OT in a standalone environment, you can publish content by running the DITA Open Toolkit through the oXygen XML Editor. With oXygen's user-friendly GUI, publishing output is as easy as clicking a button. All you need to do is select the required output from a list of scenarios and apply the transformation to your source content. The publishing scenarios include PDF, XHTML, webhelp, and other output types.
Publishing through oXygen makes sense for those in the following situations:

li.p: New DITA users. If you are new to DITA, using oXygen's simple interface to publish output may be the right choice for you. Generating output through oXygen is less confusing and requires less effort than using the DITA OT in a standalone environment.

oXygen's interface largely masks the process of running the DITA OT, which may not be optimal for users who like to watch their builds run and generate a log in real time. If you're one of these users, you may prefer to work with a standalone DITA OT.

Small content volume. If you don't have enough DITA content for a major CCMS installation, oXygen might be the right solution. Authors can create, edit, and publish their content from a single, capable tool.

Single writers or small content teams. oXygen is not freeâ€“customers must purchase an annual license to use the software. Licensing oXygen for a single writer or small team of writers for DITA publishing is generally much less costly than licensing a CCMS.

Licensing oXygen may not always be a practical investment for students or writers working on very small projects. Companies and individuals need to evaluate whether the cost of oXygen makes sense for them.
